item.title: Fingerspell.net
item.description: ASL fingerspelling practice. Flashcards for sign language students. The first and only 3D animated fingerspelling.

item.title: Grapevine.org
item.description: Giving circle and nonprofit donation platform. Make an impact together.

item.title: 101 Experiments in the Philosophy of Everyday Life
A Haunted House and Other Short Stories
A New Earth: Awakening to Your Life's Purpose
A Passionate Apprentice: The Early Journals, 1897-1909
A Path with Heart: A Guide Through the Perils and Promises of Spiritual Life
A Portrait of the Artist As a Young Man
A Short History of Nearly Everything
item.description: It started with a bang, and shortly after petered away into miniature biographies of dead white men which were entertaining and quirky but disjoint.

item.title: A Wrinkle in Time (A Wrinkle in Time Quintet, #1)
Adulthood Rites (Xenogenesis, #2)
item.description: I found this far less sensitive, sharp, or well written than the trilogy’s first book, Dawn.

item.title: Alice's Adventures in Wonderland and Through the Looking-Glass
And to Think That I Saw It on Mulberry Street
Anne of Avonlea (Anne of Green Gables, #2)
Anne of the Island (Anne of Green Gables, #3)
Art of Drawing the Human Body
Attached: The New Science of Adult Attachment and How It Can Help You Find—and Keep—Love
item.description: This was a really wonderful book for introducing me to new ways of seeing and talking about relationships.

item.title: Attack and Defense (Elementary Go Series Vol 5)
item.description: Amazing! There is so much to learn in here! A 5d friend of mine gave me this, Tesuji, and Kageyama’s Fundamentals.

item.title: Away
item.description: The peripheral characters had more personality than the main character. Depressing, but not in a moving way.

item.title: Becoming Modern: The Life of Mina Loy
Being in Love: How to Love with Awareness and Relate Without Fear
Bird by Bird: Some Instructions on Writing and Life
Breaking The Pattern: The 5 Principles You Need To Remodel Your Life
Bringing Down the House: The Inside Story of Six M.I.T. Students Who Took Vegas for Millions
Calling in "The One": 7 Weeks to Attract the Love of Your Life
item.description: This is a fantastic book! Better than I expected, given the title.

item.title: Catch-22
item.description: I stopped reading when the main characters started laughing and bragging about gang raping women to each other.

item.title: Catching Fire (The Hunger Games, #2)
item.description: I was a little worried that Collins couldn’t keep up the fantastic plot, pacing, and brilliance of The Hunger Games, but shortly into this, I stopped worrying.

item.title: Confessions of a Master Jewel Thief
Cosmicomics
item.description: If a book where a narrator uses snippets of physics “facts” and cosmological history as inspirations for fantastic situations and characters interests you, read this!

item.title: Cover to Cover: Creative Techniques for Making Beautiful Books, Journals & Albums
Culture Jam: How To Reverse America's Suicidal Consumer Binge - And Why We Must
Curious Wine
item.description: If you want interesting fiction…delightful characters…funny dialog…engaging action…artful literature…you’ll find none of that here.

item.title: Dawn (Xenogenesis, #1)
item.description: Wow. This book captured me! There are lots of difficult [and potentially troubling] issues this book brings up.

item.title: Death: The High Cost of Living
Desiring God: Meditations of a Christian Hedonist
Edgar Huntly or Memoirs of a Sleep-Walker
Fahrenheit 451
item.description: My reaction: really? THIS is great “Fahrenheit 451?” On the plot and idea level, it’s interesting and potentially lovely.

item.title: Farms with a Future: Creating and Growing a Sustainable Farm Business
Fingersmith
item.description: Off the top of my head, I cannot think of any book that has such a dumbfounding and pleasurably dark turn!

item.title: Finite and Infinite Games a Vision of Life as Play and Possibility
Gender Shock: Exploding the Myths of Male & Female
Generation T: 108 Ways to Transform a T-Shirt
Good Omens: The Nice and Accurate Prophecies of Agnes Nutter, Witch
Graded Go Problems for Beginners
item.description: A perfect book of problems for maybe 10-5k range. It breaks things into chapters dealing with life and death, ko, endgame, direction of play, etc.

item.title: Graded Go Problems For Beginners Volume Three Intermediate Problems 15 to 8 Kyu (Graded Go Problems for Beginners, #3)
item.description: A wonderful collection of Go problems! It says 20-15k, but I worked through this as 12-9k or so…it was just about right!

item.title: Hard-Boiled Wonderland and the End of the World
Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets (Harry Potter, #2)
Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows (Harry Potter, #7)
Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire (Harry Potter, #4)
Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince (Harry Potter, #6)
Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix (Harry Potter, #5)
Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban (Harry Potter, #3)
Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone (Harry Potter, #1)
Hearts That We Broke Long Ago
item.description: A poetic and heartfelt look at how we often sabotage our own efforts to find love and live out negative patterns.

item.title: How to Shit in the Woods: An Environmentally Sound Approach to a Lost Art
How to Win Friends and Influence People
I Can Read With My Eyes Shut!
If the Buddha Dated: A Handbook for Finding Love on a Spiritual Path
Images of Excellence: Plato's Critique of the Arts
Impro: Improvisation and the Theatre
item.description: Oh my god, this book is lovely. It’s “about” how to teach improvisational acting…but it’s really about relationships, creativity, imagination, and trusting your own flow and instincts.

item.title: Improvise.: Scene from the Inside Out
In the Beginning (Elementary Go Series, #1)
item.description: This and Kageyama’s Fundamentals were my first Go books. I read this as a 15-20k.

item.title: In the Palaces of Memory: How We Build the Worlds Inside Our Heads
Inspiration Sandwich: Stories to Inspire Our Creative Freedom
item.description: Dreamy, playful, and cute. Inspiration Sandwich is exactly that – food for your creative and adventurous soul.

item.title: Interview with the Vampire (The Vampire Chronicles, #1)
Introduction to the Theory of Computation
Jean Rhys: The Complete Novels (Voyage in the Dark, Quartet, After Leaving Mr Mackenzie, Good Morning, Midnight, Wide Sargasso Sea)
Johnny the Homicidal Maniac: Director's Cut
Jonathan Livingston Seagull
item.description: I enjoyed it…but not a book I’d recommend to anyone. It’s about as well written as The Alchemist… it’s the book I’d expect them to sell at Starbucks registers as an impulse buy…or a book your pretentious, well educated, but not very successful entrepreneur grandfather would give you for your 12th birthday.

item.title: Kiss the Rain
item.description: I read it despite the cover, by which you can judge this book.

item.title: Lamb: The Gospel According to Biff, Christ's Childhood Pal
Lessons in the Fundamentals of Go (Beginner and Elementary Go Books)
item.description: This and Ishigure’s “In the Beginning” were my first Go books.

item.title: Literature for Composition: Essays, Fiction, Poetry, and Drama
Living the Simple Life: A Guide to Scaling Down and Enjoying More
Looking at Movies: An Introduction to Film
Love in the Time of Cholera
Making a Literary Life: Advice for Writers and Other Dreamers
Mind Wide Open: Why You Are What You Think
MLA Handbook for Writers of Research Papers
Mockingjay (The Hunger Games, #3)
item.description: You know how some relationships are really amazing? And then it gets bad, but it was so good before that you hope the magic might come back?

item.title: My Side of the Mountain (Mountain, #1)
item.description: This was one of my favorite books when I was little.

item.title: On Writing: A Memoir of the Craft
Once Upon a Time (Nightmares & Fairy Tales, #1)
One Fish, Two Fish, Red Fish, Blue Fish
Oranges Are Not the Only Fruit
item.description: Would I enjoy this as much if the protagonist wasn’t a lesbian?

item.title: Out of the Silent Planet (The Space Trilogy, #1)
item.description: Wondrous! Everything about this Ransom’s adventure to the planet Malacandra is wondrous!

item.title: Perelandra (The Space Trilogy, #2)
item.description: Meh. After adoring its prequel, “Out of the Silent Planet,” and remembering enjoying this when I was younger, I had high expectations for “Perelandra.

item.title: Please Understand Me II: Temperament, Character, Intelligence
PostSecret: Extraordinary Confessions from Ordinary Lives (PostSecret)
Practical Intuition in Love: Start a Journey Through Pleasure to the Love of Your Life
Rich Dad, Poor Dad: What the Rich Teach Their Kids about Money-That the Poor and the Middle Class Do Not!
Selected Poems of William Carlos Williams
She Loves Me, She Loves Me Not: Romantic Fiction
She's Not There: A Life in Two Genders
Spoon Fed: How Eight Cooks Saved My Life
item.description: Light, grounded, and pretty fun to read. I liked her laid back style—Kim seems like someone I’d like to know.

item.title: Squee's Wonderful Big Giant Book of Unspeakable Horrors.
Stranger in a Strange Land
item.description: Core message of the book: heterosexual sex is the greatest achievement of the universe.

item.title: Stupid Sock Creatures: Making Quirky, Lovable Figures from Cast-off Socks
Switch Hitters: Lesbians Write Gay Male Erotica and Gay Men Write Lesbian Erotica
Tesuji (Elementary Go Series, #3)
item.description: Amazing! There is so much to learn in here! A 5d friend of mine gave me this, Attack and Defense, and Kageyama’s Fundamentals.

item.title: The Alchemist
item.description: Bad, bad bad. The tale of it—the plot—wasn’t too offensive, but Coelho’s writing felt artificial, preachy, and pretentious.

item.title: The Art of Fiction: Notes on Craft for Young Writers
The Art of Rozz Williams: From Christian Death to Death
The Ballad of Songbirds and Snakes (The Hunger Games, #0)
The Baron in the Trees
item.description: In a word: Delightful! If “Invisible Cities” excited me by Italo Calvino’s ability as an inspiring writer, then “The Baron in the Trees” excited me by his facility as a story-teller.

item.title: The Bisexual's Guide to the Universe: Quips, Tips, and Lists for Those Who Go Both Ways
The Blank Slate: The Modern Denial of Human Nature
The Book Thief
item.description: I’m over halfway through this book, and I’m giving it up.

item.title: The Castle of Crossed Destinies
item.description: The idea of the story is intriguing: mute travelers tell stories to each other with a tarot deck and some gestures.

item.title: The Complete Novels: Voyage in the Dark / Quartet / After Leaving Mr Mackenzie / Good Morning, Midnight / Wide Sargasso Sea
The Complete Works of Shakespeare [38 plays 4 poems, sonnets]
The Darwin Awards II: Unnatural Selection (Darwin Awards, #2)
The Darwin Awards: Evolution in Action (Darwin Awards, #1)
The Direction of Play
item.description: Wow! I love Takeo’s writing style. He approaches the game with such a reverence and intensity.

item.title: The Essential Enneagram
item.description: I’ve been interested in the MBTI model for quite awhile, and I’m just starting to look into enneagram literature.

item.title: The Foot Book: Dr. Seuss's Wacky Book of Opposites
The Golden Key
item.description: Beautiful and filled with evocative images and ideas, to be sure.

item.title: The Great Divorce
item.description: I enjoyed this for the ideas if nothing else. It felt a little pretentious and consciously-poised…of course the main character was the open-minded observer of other people’s short sightedness.

item.title: The Happiness Project
item.description: Platitudes, banal moralizing, and unimaginative anecdotes from a self-impressed writer. There is nothing particularly horrible about this book.

item.title: The Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy (Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy, #1)
item.description: Five stars for droll, absurd style and humor. Three stars for it becoming old really quickly.

item.title: The Hobbit, or There and Back Again
The Hunger Games (The Hunger Games, #1)
item.description: So delightful! I read this in two sittings. It’s as smooth, enjoyable, dark, painful, and wonderful as a survivalist gladiatorial 1984 romance should be!

item.title: The Letters of Abélard and Héloïse
The Lost Lunar Baedeker: Poems of Mina Loy
The Market Gardener: A Handbook for Successful Small-Scale Organic Farming
The Missing Piece Meets the Big O
The Night Circus
item.description: I enjoyed this book, but wouldn’t wholeheartedly recommend it. The circus and magic are intriguing and fun!

item.title: The Organic Farmer's Business Handbook
item.description: This book gave me a pretty clear picture of what it takes to maintain a farm from the business perspective - legally, practically, etc.

item.title: The Organic Farming Manual: A Comprehensive Guide to Starting and Running a Certified Organic Farm
item.description: As a farmer-to-be, this was the first book I read on farming, and it was the perfect intro for me.

item.title: The Penguin Dictionary of Literary Terms and Literary Theory
The Powerbook
item.description: Full of enjoyable stories of love, romance, seeking, and finding. It’s a fun book, and like most Winterson novels, seems to dig into little crevices in your heart and mind you didn’t know existed.

item.title: The Queen of the Damned (The Vampire Chronicles, #3)
The Secret World of Slugs and Snails: Life in the Very Slow Lane
The Sense of an Ending
item.description: While it certainly had interesting, funny, and sometimes even wise moments, thoughts, emotions, and characters, the book felt a little dull throughout.

item.title: The Sense of Being Stared At: And Other Unexplained Powers of the Human Mind
The Soul of an Octopus: A Surprising Exploration Into the Wonder of Consciousness
The Soul of Soil: A Soil-Building Guide for Master Gardeners and Farmers
item.description: Super informative, but scattered presentation. It felt more like “fact, fact, fact, fact…” than the name “The Soul of the Soil” would lead me to believe.

item.title: The Tao of Tango
item.description: Johanna has a really lovely idea here - exploring and explaining masculine and feminine energies through tango.

item.title: The Universe in Your Hand: A Journey Through Space, Time, and Beyond
The Unsettling of America: Culture & Agriculture
item.description: This book is beautiful. It is difficult to read because it is deep, lengthy, and analyzing a depressing situation; but it is wondrous in its insight, poignancy, and thought-filled-ness.

item.title: The Upright Citizens Brigade Comedy Improvisation Manual
item.description: A wonderful, well-presented, and clearly-thought-through approach to improv and comedy. Contains plentiful exercises as well, which makes it a good improv-practice-group guide.

item.title: The Woman Who Walked Into Doors (Paula Spencer, #1)
This is ok!
item.description: H1 in content. Yes, great content! And an H2 Yes, great content!

item.title: Tipping the Velvet
item.description: Beautiful, fun, sexy, wonderous. This book is an incredible adventure, and, rare for a longer work, deserves every page it’s printed on plus a rereading in the not-too-distant future.

item.title: Truth in Comedy: The Manual of Improvisation
item.description: I can’t recommend this book at all. It’s very self-absorbed, full of name-dropping, and narrow in scope and perspective.

item.title: Verse Writing, A Practical Handbook for College Classes and Private Guidance
Virginia Woolf A to Z: A Comprehensive Reference to Her Life, Works, and Critical Reception
Wilderness Survival Handbook: Primitive Skills for Short-Term Survival and Long-Term Comfort
Written on the Body
item.description: Not the most enjoyable plot or characters…they both felt a little vacuous.

item.title: Young Goodman Brown and Other Short Stories
Your Time Has Come
item.description: Delightful! A cute and intelligent book of short, witty, and playful poems.

item.title: Zen and the Art of Motorcycle Maintenance: An Inquiry Into Values (Phaedrus, #1)
